ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed a strong intuition and understanding of organometallic and coordination complexes as well as catalytic cycles that I could then apply to a wide variety of cases. The first third of the course taught about the nature of inorganic compounds and how to characterize them, all of which was a buildup to the middle third, organometallic reactions and catalysis. In the final third, we focused on some applications, including climate change, "blunders" (errors made by scientists), and bioinorganics.

Knowledge of transition metals and their coordination, knowledge of organometallic and catalytic mechanisms, ability to digest and understand complicated test problems by applying specific pieces of knowledge.
Inorganic
Gen chem, some basic organometallic and coordination chemistry, random fun facts and bloopers
Knowledge of inorganic chemistry including catalytic cycles and green chemistry

Knowledge: the main facets of inorganic chemistry (atoms, ions and lattices, materials, complex and substitution,
catalysis, electron transfer, climate, bio-inorganic), it really is a very comprehensive course and so fascinating because
the materials are just related enough to organic or biochemistry but from a very di!erent approach, or o!ers another
layer of complexity (e.g. Grignard reagents, enzyme catalysis, etc);

Skills: test taking (the two midterms are only 50 mins long, so sometimes it is about learning what topics and concepts
are most important to study for), learning skills (finding a right balance of rewatching lecture, reading textbook, study
group with classmates, etc), fundamental concepts in inorganic chemistry;

Insights: there were some rather fascinating stories and examples of "how to do science" that would be broadly
transferable to any other field, not just limited to Chemistry
I developed an understanding of how periodic trends can predict crystal structure, bond character, oxidation state, and catalytic activity for complexes of transition-metal elements.
An overview of different topics in inorganic chemistry
Learned inorganic chemistry
I learned more about a critical-thinking approach to chemistry, especially involving inorganic processes.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class covered a lot of interesting material but lacked a cohesive structure, making it difficult to understand concepts.

Strengths: deliberate pauses during lectures to ask for questions, detailed summaries of what is and isn't important, important slides marked, lecture notes posted to Canvas -- all of these organizational features are surprisingly difficult to find among professors and make such a big difference for students. Additionally, I really liked the small group work/pair work during discussion sections. I also really appreciated the emphasis on understanding and intuition rather than memorization, as well as the generous partial credit he would give for an answer that used correct reasoning, even if it wasn't what he was going for.

Weaknesses: The course was a bit low-engagement. Aside from the pauses to ask for questions, lectures were 50 minutes of Professor Crabtree reading from a slide deck (which, to be fair, is true of most lecture courses). I wish that there had been more opportunities to work through problems as a group, or participation problems during classes, asking questions to the class for us to answer, etc. That being said, discussion section definitely provided a lot of that engagement. The other weakness would be the vague grading scheme. I had confidence that Professor Crabtree would work out the grades in a way that benefited us, but getting conflicting messages about whether or not the number grades matter and being told that the curve was based on class rank without having any way of knowing what that class rank was definitely created a lot of stress for me.

I don't want any of this to come across as if I didn't enjoy this course. Professor Crabtree cares deeply about making great scientists out of his students. It's evident from the way he focuses on intuition over memorization, the way he taught us to avoid errors in our science, and the way that he gave generous partial credit to any answer that makes sense -- he wanted to reward good thought. I'm glad I got to take his course before he retires.

The strengths of this course are, in my opinion, the sheer amount of material discussed and the wide variety of topics that are presented. I greatly enjoyed learning about organometallic and metallic chemistry, a topic which I had largely never seen before. The course is taught through PowerPoint slides, which makes locating the material much easier for problem sets and discussion sections. The professor, TA, and peer tutor were all very helpful and available outside of class time.
A lot of material
The information is poorly structured. Grading is stressful and harsh. Exams are so random

In some sense, the strength and weakness of the course are the same: the material covered is very broad and
comprehensive, which is very intriguing and really allows students to explore the di!erent facets of inorganic
chemistry (and perhaps research directions, especially when the Prof and TA are open to discuss their own
experiences) but also makes the course in some ways harder (to study for at least) than a higher level inorganic
chemistry course. Then the individual student experience may be rather dependent on the TA and the study groups
that they form before or throughout the course.

The course had a good balance between concepts and applications. I would have liked to have learned more about environmental applications of inorganic chemistry, such as water oxidation and carbon dioxide reduction.

It was nice that it was recorded because I was able to go back and rewatch parts that I did not understand. The lecture format was overall extremely difficult to follow and would have been nice if it was more interactive. The way material was presented was so confusing that it made me confused about topics that were being retaught from previous chemistry courses that I already knew well. In the end I ended up trying to ignore what was taught in this class and go back to the way I had previously perceived the material.
The lecture was not very engaging due to the virtual format and the slides were a bit hard to understand at times -- more practice of the material would have been very helpful.
The discussion sections were very helpful for thinking of the lessons in a different way, and the lectures were done the same way. No weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having comprehensive lecture slides was very helpful, but the need to attend synchronous discussion sections was annoying.

I love having recorded lectures posted to watch multiple times -- it really helps me learn. Other aspects of the course stayed largely the same. Professor Crabtree noted at one point that he got through his material in less lectures than normal because on a zoom with everyone's camera off and no interaction between him and the students, the material goes much more quickly. He added that he normally tells jokes, which he eliminated this semester as they are hard to tell over zoom -- I mourn the loss of what I'm sure are some excellent Crabtree jokes!!
Not very effective over zoom. Pace of class was different from regular semester which hindered learning

Success: The in person live components (with lecture being recorded, and section/office hour not) were really helpful
for this class in particularly for the students to stay engaged. It helped understanding and collaboration in lot of
instances (especially as some of the questions that people might have are class-specific as the Prof. has his own
definitions and notations sometimes);

Improvement: Practically nobody had camera on during lecture, and the Prof. had to turn theirs o! sometimes
because of wi# bandwidth issues at home, so (as the Prof. re"ects as well) the pace of the class was particularly fast
because there was no eye contact or looking at how fast people are taking notes to slow down (and reduced the
amount of stories). We #nished the material almost four classes before previous years.

Because of the virtual lecture format, the class was more fast-paced than in a normal year and at times hard to follow. However, recorded lectures were an asset that allowed me to review concepts I hadn't understood.
It was really helpful that lectures were recorded
The recorded lectures were helpful so that students could learn at their own pace when needed
No improvements needed.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really did enjoy this course. I found inorganic chemistry more rigorous than organic -- there's a level of attention to detail and wanting to explain exactly how a phenomenon comes about that is sometimes replaced by hand-waving in organic lectures. Professor Crabtree is incredibly knowledgeable and cares deeply about the topic as well.

I would recommend this class to another student; I think in past years, this class may have not received the rating it fully deserved. The course does review the essential topics of inorganic chemistry, and explores catalytic mechanisms, which I found the highlight of the semester. I greatly enjoyed my time in Professor Crabtree's class, and would highly recommend it to anyone considering the chemistry major. The reality is that he is retiring and thus will not be teaching the course in the future; I imagine it will be taught differently in the future. I will speak to the material: it is super interesting! We basically went through (almost) every chapter of Professor Crabtree's book, occasionally skipping over a few topics or concepts. I found his book very clear, and a great reinforcement of the material. A great class to take if you are interested in the chemistry major, wanting to determine whether to pursue chemistry, or simply interested in metals and catalysis.
Not unless you have to. It wasnt that interesting and didnt provide too much value

Most of the class is Chemistry majors (or at least strongly intended), though there are occasional Chemical
Engineering majors in the class (unfortunately I don't think it wold count towards the degree). I do think the course is
very good for anyone interested related #elds especially bio-inorganics and materials sciences! (This being said, the
course design and coverage will likely change in the future as it will be a di!erent Prof.)
Yes. If the student has an interest in inorganic chemistry, this course is a relatively rigorous introduction to it without an overly demanding workload.
Not if you do not have to. The material is extremely interesting but the way it was presented made me want to drop out of Yale.

Not in this format -- the lectures were very difficult to follow and the course made me confused about chemistry concepts that should have been easy. I think that in different circumstances this could be a very interesting class, but this semester was just tough. However, if you already have a strong background in chemistry and are prepared to do some self-teaching then it could be a good class to take.
I would, as it is introduces chemistry students to a higher level of critical thinking in chemistry than I have seen before.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Lectures were recorded and posted online. There was also weekly virtual discussion section and office hours.
Virtual Discussion
Online virtual discussion section

50 mins in person live virtual three times a week, then 1 hour separate virtual o$ce hour for Prof and TA, and 1 hour
session (of 2 choices) each week with TA
Lectures were recorded
Lectures are recorded, sections were live/virtual
Discussion Section was performed virtually.
